eadid.publicid: -//State University of New York at Buffalo::Music Library//TEXT (US::NBuU-Mu::Mus. Arc. 30::Recordings of June in Buffalo)//EN

titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Recordings of June in Buffalo, 1975-1978, 1980
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by John Bewley.
titlestmt.sponsor: Preservation and digitization performed by George Blood Audio funded by a grant from the J. Warren and Charles Donald Perry Memorial Fund administered by the Community Foundation of Greater Buffalo.

publicationstmt.publisher: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library
publicationstmt.p: © 2011. State University of New York at Buffalo. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded in EAD by John Bewley, October, 2011.

change.item: The finding aid was updated with the addition of a series for the John Cage lecture recordings.

did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: Recordings of June in Buffalo, 1975-1978, 1980

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Dept.

did.physdesc: 9 linear feet (64 reel to reel tapes, 179 audio compact discs, 58 DVDs)
did.materialspec: The reformatted contents are on two sets of 79 CDs: one is labeled Service Copy, the other is labeled In-house Master. They contain audio files at 44.1kHz/16bit resolution. The 58 DVDs are labeled Preservation Master and contain WAV files at 96kHZ/24bit resolution. The John Cage lecture recordings were reformatted separately. They were reformatted as CD-R 44.1kHZ 16bit files and are contained on 3 sets of 7 CDs each: service copy, in-house master, and preservation master.
did.physloc: The reel to reel tapes are currently housed in Music Library Storage (B-32). The preservation masters are located in the Music Library's Treasure Room.
did.langmaterial: Collection material includes spoken word recordings in English.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: State University of New York at Buffalo. Music Library

did.abstract: The collection contains recordings of fifty-one of the fifty-three concerts presented at the June in Buffalo festival from 1975-1978 and in 1980. Approximately 216 works were recorded as well as some spoken introductions to works by their respective composers. The collection also contains recordings of three of the five lecture-seminars presented by John Cage during June in Buffalo 1975.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Specified item], Recordings of June in Buffalo, 1975-1978, 1980, Music Library, The State University of New York at Buffalo.

accessrestrict.head: Terms of Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials can be examined by qualified researchers in the Music Library during hours of operation during which Music Librarians are present. In order to insure access, researchers are advised to contact the Music Library in advance of visits.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Copyright for the materials in the collection does not reside with the Music Library. Additionally, performers' permissions were not acquired at the time of the recordings. Therefore, patrons wishing to publish any item, or part of an item from this collection for any purpose, are responsible for securing requisite permissions.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of State University of New York at Buffalo Music Dept.

accruals.head: Accruals and Additions
accruals.p: No further accruals are expected to this collection.

altformavail.head: Alternate Forms
altformavail.p: The original recordings were made on reel-to-reel tapes (all but two are 10 inch reels). The contents were digitized in 2007 onto CDs (service and in-house masters) and DVDs (preservation masters). Preservation wav files that match the original reel faces are named with roots that match the concert numbering, for example preservation files for the first concert are named JIB01_01.wav and JIB01_02.wav. The CD audio files on the Service CDs match the works presented at the concerts. Wav files were created from these files and are named using the work numbers listed in the container list with the addition of the suffix "sc" for service copy. For example, the first concert contains four works represented by files named JIB01_001_sc.wav, JIB01_002_sc.wav, JIB01_003_sc.wav, and JIB01_004_sc.wav. The preservation files and service files were also offloaded from the CDs and DVDs to the Institutional Repository.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The June in Buffalo festival of contemporary music was established by Morton Feldman in 1975. Morton Feldman joined the University at Buffalo Music Faculty in 1972. He was the Slee Professor, 1972-1973, Edgar Varèse Professor, 1975-1987, and the Director of the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts, 1976-1980. Feldman established the June in Buffalo festival in 1975 as a counterpart to the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts' successful Evenings for New Music concerts. The new festival was presented 1975-1978, and again in 1980, with a year off in 1979 when Feldman was on sabbatical. The festival was revived in 1986 by composer David Felder.

In addition to presenting concerts, Feldman's festival created a seminar environment in which student composers attended workshops where distinguished composers-in-residence rehearsed their works and gave lectures. Feldman also wanted to create a more intense listening experience by presenting programs that contained multiple works by a single composer. To that end, twelve works by John Cage were presented on the three concerts that opened the first festival in June 1975. Other single-composer programs were devoted to the works of Christian Wolff, Ralph Shapey, George Crumb, Lejaren Hiller, Nils Vigeland, Steve Reich, Charles Wuorinen, Henry Brant, Elliott Carter, Stefan Wolpe, Milton Babbitt, Lou Harrison, Earle Brown, and Aaron Copland. Works by earlier twentieth-century composers, including Ives, Schoenberg, Satie, Cowell, Webern, Berg, and Bártók were also presented on June in Buffalo programs. Three works received their United States premieres and five works received their world premieres at the festival. All concerts but one were held in what was then called Baird Hall (now Allen Hall) on what is now the South Campus. The June 1, 1976 concert was held at the Albright Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains recordings for 51 of the 53 concerts that were presented 1975-1980 as part of the June in Buffalo concert series. It contains approximately 216 works. There are several instances of composers providing spoken introductions to their own works. The original recordings were made on reel-to-reel tapes (all but two are 10 inch reels). The contents were digitized in 2007 onto CDs (service and in-house masters) and DVDs (preservation masters).

Please note that this finding aid contains a description of the recorded concerts. However, the container list also reflects single works that were not recorded along with the rest of a concert program, such as when tapes were played of electronic works. Two complete concerts were not recorded: Concerts 7 and 34. Concert 7 (17 June 1975) consisted of performances of the two piano sonatas of Charles Ives. Piano sonata 1 was performed by Nils Vigeland; Piano sonata 2 was performed by Yvar Mikhashoff. Concert 34 (2 June 1978) featured performances by violinist Paul Zukofsky and pianist Ursula Oppens in John Cage's Cheap imitation (violin alone) and Six melodies, and Morton Feldman's Spring of Chosroes.

John Cage presented five lecture-seminars during June in Buffalo 1975. Of these, the collection has recordings of the three seminars presented June 4, 5, and 6. These seminars by visiting composers were an integral part of Morton Feldman's plan for the festival. The presentations by Cage are of interest because they are unscripted, spontaneous discussions rather than the prepared lectures he often presented. His interactions with the students and his digressions from reviewing their compositions provide glimpses of his personality and his aesthetics. The June 5 lecture is notable for containing Cage's dramatic response to a performance of his Song Books by the S.E.M. Ensemble on June 4.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two series:

did.unittitle:
Concert recordings, 1975-1978,
1980

arrangement.p: The concert recordings are arranged in chronological order by concert. The descriptions pertain to entire concert programs. Reels 3-6 contain the John Cage lectures found in Series II.

scopecontent.p: Introductory remarks to the first work by Milton Babbitt are on a separate track, with additional remarks preceding each of the other works. Comments introducing the second work are on the end of the first track, the comments introducing the third work are on the end of the second track, the comments introducing the fourth work are on a separate track, and comments introducing the fifth work are on the end of the fourth track.

did.unittitle: John Cage lectures, June 4-June 6 1975

arrangement.p: The compact discs are arranged in order matching the numbering of the original reel to reel tapes, Reel 03-Reel 06.

scopecontent.p: The spines of the original containers of the reel to reel tapes are dated June 3, June 4, and June 5; the spine of the fourth reel is missing. The reformatted CDs were all incorrectly dated June 3 1975. However, auditioning the recordings reveals dates as stated below. The June 5 and June 6 are dated with certainty; the June 4 dates are less certain. Jeff Simon wrote an article in the June 21 1975 Buffalo Evening News titled "Composer Cage: Stung by followers". It contains details, including specific quotations of remarks by Cage, about lectures presented by Cage on June 2, June 3, and June 5. None of the details from the June 2 and June 3 lectures can be matched to content on the recordings below.

did.unittitle: John Cage lectures at June in Buffalo, June 4 1975 and June 5 1975

note.p: Transferred to CD 80-81. Preservation master on CD Box 3 CD 1-2.

list.item: CD 80, Track 1 (11:00): June 4 1975 (Wednesday). First spoken line: "…such an exchange of ideas … among those exchanges Christian [Wolff] brought to me the I ching which had been published by his father."
CD 80, Track 2 (24:44): June 5 1975 (Thursday). This is the first part of the lecture in which Cage responds to the S.E.M. performance of Song Books on Wednesday June 4.
CD 81, Track 1 (10:20): June 5 1975 (Thursday). This is the second part of the lecture in which Cage responds to the S.E.M. performance of Song Books on Wednesday June 4.
CD 81, Track 2 (24:43): June 5 1975 (Thursday). This is the third part of the lecture in which Cage responds to the S.E.M. performance of Song Books on Wednesday June 4.

p.emph: Online access to the recording of the lecture and an annotated transcription has generously been made available courtesy of the John Cage Trust.

did.unittitle: John Cage lecture at June in Buffalo, June 4 1975

note.p: Transferred to CD 82-83. Preservation master on CD Box 3 CD 3-4.

list.item: CD 82, Track 1 (61:41): June 4 1975 (Wednesday). First spoken line: "This morning at the rehearsal, not all of you were there, we got involved in a discussion towards the end [about] the publication of music."
CD 83, Track 1 (32:24): June 4 1975 (Wednesday). First spoken line: "But find out how to go on and I would warn against coming down to depending on your spontaneity."

did.unittitle: John Cage lecture at June in Buffalo, June 6 1975

note.p: Transferred to CD 84-85. Preservation master on CD Box 3 CD 5-6.

list.item: CD 84, Track 1 (55:10): June 6 1975 (Friday). Begins with Cage telling a story about Lois Long and Morton Feldman.
CD 85, Track 1 (40:56): June 6 1975 (Friday). Begins with a continuation of a discussion of Georgia O'Keefe's paintings.

did.unittitle: John Cage lecture at June in Buffalo, June 6 1975

note.p: Transferred to CD 86. Preservation master on CD Box 3 CD 7.

list.item: CD 86, Track 1 (31:31): June 6 1975 (Friday). Begins with Cage in the midst of reviewing a student composer's work.
